segments.text: Testing, testing, one, two, three, four, testing, testing, one, two, three, four.
Testing, four, three, two, one, four, three, two, one, testing, four, three, two, one.
This is test, testing, X, Y, Z, X, Y, Z.
One, two, three, one, two, three.
This is, I believe, Monday, the 27th of August, and we're in the Evans Library, room 206.
And today I have the pleasure of chatting with a longtime neighbor and friend, Dr. Joe Dixon, professor of soil and crop sciences.
To begin with, to introduce you to anyone who might listen or read, give a biographical sketch of yourself.
Where did you grow up and what did mom and dad do and what did you do, where did you go to high school and then college and any other experience
before you moved here?
I was born in Clinton, Kentucky, which is the county seat of Hickman County, Kentucky, on the very western end of the state.
My mother was a schoolteacher there off and on during my early life.
and my father, Jack Dixon, was also a teacher and an administrator.
He served as principal of some schools in the county and eventually was superintendent of schools in the county and unfortunately died when I was a small child and I had his example but not
his advice from day to day.
And my stepfather was a farmer, so I grew up on the farm in Hickman County and attended the public schools there and graduated from a rural school called Fulgham, which is not existent today.
The schools have been consolidated in Clinton, the county seat.
From there, I went to Murray State College, it was then, Murray State University now, and got two years of my academic work off.
And I had some vision that I might want to go on for graduate work someday, so I transferred to the University of Kentucky in Lexington.
and continued my bachelor's work and completed it there in 52.
And at that time, the Korean conflict was underway.
And so I looked for a job, but I wasn't very employable.
I eventually went to work with the Extension Service, Agricultural Extension Service, that is, in the neighboring county to my home county.
And while I was in Fulton County, I had some good experience with agricultural extension, 4-H club and such.
But then the military called me in and I served during the Korean conflict, getting my training and then eventually going to Korea and serving there and going back and forth to Japan a bit.
And so I had some Far Eastern experience that was beneficial to the government and to me.
And then, while I was there, I was contacted by W.A.C.
Dr. C. was the professor in soil science, agronomy, at the University of Kentucky.
and he had gone through the records of students that had good marks and sent us an invitation to apply for graduate study.
And so I responded to that and that was a happy situation in that I was pleased to get started on a master's degree and of course the GI Bill was available and that gave me some financial support.
I was actually married during the last term as my bachelor
period and my wife Martha Jane came and worked at the University of Kentucky for that less than a year that I had to finish out.
And then she returned to West Kentucky and waited there while I was in the military.
So we returned then to the University of Kentucky and finished my bachelor's there in 56 and by then I had an offer to come to
University of Wisconsin on a wharf, a fellowship, which was also nice to go along with the GI Bill.
And I pursued my doctoral degree in soil science under a well-known professor, M.L.
Jackson, in the soil science department at the University of Wisconsin.
And when I completed it in 58, there were jobs in those days because PhDs were not all that abundant in soil science.
and universities were expanding their graduate programs.

But I wasn't too pleased with the offerings so I accepted a National Science Foundation fellowship and stayed at the University of Wisconsin for a year and did some teaching and went back and took up some courses that I had missed when I went through the first time because I started in a small college.
and anticipating a job at Auburn University, which I did take then at the end of 59.
And I served at Auburn on the faculty as assistant professor and I believe associate before I left in the growing program in the agronomy and soils department there.
And in nine years, I was there.
And during that period, I served as a member and then eventually the chairman of a committee, which is still going on today on soil mineralogy throughout the southeastern 13 states.
George W. Coonsey was on that committee also.
And when he got an offer to come up as dean of the graduate college at Texas A&M, he invited me to come and look at his post here.
And I must say it was not exactly an easy decision because at Auburn I had a lot of new research equipment, a new building, and I had sort of come from rags to riches there.
money was more available in those days for research and teaching.

And yet I liked the potential to come to Texas A&M because it's a larger university and I wanted to be able to specialize, whereas at Auburn I taught geology, undergraduate soils, graduate soils, and soil mineralogy, my specialty.
Well, I didn't feel I could reach my potential with such a broad selection of courses to teach.
And so I came to A&M.
I think I came here for about $9,000 a year.
Now, what year was that?
And that was in 1968.
As far as you were aware, what reputation in the general area
of Soil and Crop Sciences did A&M have then as an institution?
Well, it was a growing institution.
We were in a very old building, one of the very oldest ones here at A&M.
At that time, they did have some new research equipment that had gotten a few years before.
But in general it was, just speaking now just about the physical conditions where I came to work, they were not very good.
But I could see a lot of potential here because at that time the bringing aboard of co-education was in sight and there was a distinct spirit of growth

and the challenge that was given to me here particularly was that they wanted to build a world-class university and I appreciated that then and more through the years so I always considered the whole world my opportunity and so I started things that took me overseas occasionally and it shaped my whole career here.
Describe
the process that led to your being selected?
As far as you're aware, were they looking at other people?
Did you come visit?
Did they sit with you somewhere?
And was there an interview and so forth?
Yes, I came here.
As I reflect on it now, I came here by myself and looked at the job.
And Dr. Morris Bloodworth interviewed me and showed me around, and I remember him showing me a soil physics laboratory and saying, isn't that typical of the mass of a soil physics laboratory?
That's rather characteristic.
They're not the tidiest of facilities, usually.
And in general, I sort of had that impression of what I saw.
but I still liked the future prospects and I'd say A&M was emerging in my view.
Did you meet some other senior people on that trip?

Yes, I met Curtis Godfrey who was here and Curtis was a very personable man and had a lot of experience in the field and I liked that very much because he was doing what had been half of my position back in Auburn and so
I realized then I had a colleague who would tell me about things in the field that I wouldn't have to embrace them all.
And he asked good stimulating questions that I can recall that was good for me as well as hopefully for him.
And of course, George Kunze was still around and he was a gracious host.
And his wife, they had me in their home and
and shared some good German sausage with me and things like that.
So I felt very much at home.
Also, Grant Thomas, who was a chemist that I had known by reputation, he was here.
And I remember visiting with him.
So in general, I was quite pleased with the personnel.
During that visit, did anything go wrong?
Were there any goofs that anybody made or anything get confused or mixed up?
I don't really have any negative reflections on that visit except it was a dreary time of the year and
I came in here by air, and when I left, I remember, and it was the airplane, it was a very small airplane.
Davis Airlines?
Davis Airlines, and I remember when the pilot got in, and I got in behind him and closed the door.
And in that situation,
rainy season in that small aircraft, I felt this was some experience, shall we say.
It wasn't all roses, by any means.
When you got home, what did you tell your wife about the trip?
Well, I think I told her that while it didn't look very glamorous, but I thought that it would be good for us in the long run.
And then we came back together, drove over, and with our children, and did, after we had agreed to take the post, looked and purchased a house, as a matter of fact, while we were here.
of which you know Dr. Monroe was near where you later built a house.
It was already built?
It was built, but it wasn't quite finished.
And so we got the privilege of going through and making selections of colors if we needed to make any.
Most of them were already made.
But we did have the privilege of saying some things and approving others.
So it was...
on the extreme.
Make believe that I had never been here before.
Describe where that was in terms of the edge of town and how you got to that house at that point.
How did you, what roads led to it?
Well, as I remember, we went down Texas Avenue and then we turned on Southwest Parkway, but it was not a parkway much in that day.
In fact, the street development was incomplete, as I recall it.
Maybe in front of the house there was a street and that far in, but I think on out toward Wellborn Road it had not been completed at that time.
And was there anything south of,
In terms of streets being laid out, there was nothing south of that one.
I don't think so.
I think that the word I got was that Mr. Fitch had 400 acres that lay south and that he was going to develop that.
And that's more or less what happened, I think.
Describe then the move for you and the family.
How did it go?
It went quite well.
We did things in a frugal way.
We had a Volkswagen and a Chevrolet, and we tagged the Volkswagen on the back of the Chevrolet and drove over.
And our furniture and things came by van, Mayflowers, I recall.
And I think the only problem that came when we got here, Martha said, those hats of mine look like they're in bad conditions.
And she reported that to the carrier and two people, two gentlemen came out from the local trucking firm in Bryan and they were afraid she was one of the men of money.
for those hats.
That wasn't quite the case, but they managed that all right.
What was your, in the first months you were here, what was your impression of Texans and of people in Bryan and College Station?
How were you received?
Well, I think pretty well.
I remember the first day we went to A&M Methodist Church, there was a short little gentleman, very frail in body, named Bryson.

He met us in the Northex of the church and I think he had gotten wind of the fact that we were here to look for a job or taking a job and so he sort of picked up the ball at that point and made us feel very welcome in the church and then visited us and the minister visited us at home.
I would say that that was a singular point that made us feel quite welcome here.
Fred Bryson.
Yeah, Fred Bryson.
Was this in the summer that you all moved?
Yes, we moved in early June, as I recall, and I think my appointment only started at the end of the month, or the first of July, perhaps.
In other words, we had a period.
I remember asking Morris Bloodworth when I came, well, what should I do with this time between now I've arrived and that?
He said, well, you take a good vacation because you're going to need it, something to that effect.
How was the heat for a newcomer?
Well, we made our adjustments, but that wasn't exactly a rosy experience because the grass on the lawn hadn't been established and the heat came on.
But it was a moist year, a spring anyway, so we had plenty of water at that time and we managed things all right.
And we had help from the builder who was building a house next door when it came to establishing the lawn.
He loans us a tractor and
And across the street there was Babe and Art Nightingale, and they were very hospitable and helpful.
and of course gave some professional advice on furniture and things.
So we felt very much at home.
The Rusynks were living down the street and they were obviously very friendly people and they had children about the age of ours.
So all those things made life pleasant even though we might have had to drive over some dirt street to get to some places.
Right, then you get to the campus, describe your office and research facilities.
Okay, the office was on the west side of the old state chemist building, which I think is about the second oldest building on campus, and two large hybrid live oaks just outside the window.
and I remember those because that shade was so important because that window air conditioner worked awfully hard and having some shade there made it more pleasant, temperature-wise and viewing-wise.
Being a very old building, there was a lot of disorder, but Dr. Kunze had fenced off the x-ray machine lab, which had to be humidity controlled, and that meant that I had two cool spots.
One of them was in the x-ray room and the other one was in my office.
And in between, the temperature varied.
But I was rather pleased to have some technical help during those days.
And actually, technical help was more available then.
And then I inherited a student from Dr. Kunze.
And we collaborated some.
So it was, and a lot of the other equipment inside the x-ray machine was quite old, and we struggled with that a bit.
But new things were coming aboard, and some of my colleagues in soil chemistry helped by sharing some of that.
So it was a period of growth, and that made it more attractive, even though the surroundings in that building were
It was a bit dismal at times.
Describe the department, about how big was it and who were the big names, who were the well-known people?
Well, as I mentioned earlier, Curtis Godfrey was well-known for his work in soil taxonomy.
And Grant Thomas had not been here so long, but he was a flamboyant sort of person.
And he was known throughout the country, and it was nice to have him as a colleague.
But unfortunately, he didn't last very long.
He got, I think, into a little tight somehow and was offered a job elsewhere.
And he, in fact, went to the University of Kentucky, which is my old alma mater.
But he probably did that regrettably because I know he came back and collaborated for a few years, but somehow he didn't fit the social scene here like he wanted to, I think.
But we had, I remember, a TVA representative here at that time that kept us in touch with Tennessee Valley Authority, which provided particular fertilizer formulations.
And that linked the federal...
fertilizer development laboratories with the university and he managed a program here.
I know his name, although at the moment I can't call it for you.
About how many faculty in the department then?
That's always been a difficult question to answer at A&M.
We had, now Alan Swoboda was a young faculty member and I enjoyed collaborating with him.
He later became a builder in the local community.
I always thought of the department as having about two dozen faculty and about half of them were soils and about half of them were crops.
But now that's...
that's generalizing quite a bit.
Because, see, we have about a dozen research and extension centers scattered throughout the state.
And those people are interactive with us and we with them.
And therefore, usually when you look at statistics on size, we would come up with 60 to 75 people involved.
And more than half of those were located at these research and extension centers.
And that was great for me.
I'm a soil mineralogist.
I like to study different kinds of soil and having some people working on rice down at Beaumont and reducing the environment, chemically speaking.
And then other people working at Overton and deep sandy soils and deep-rooted crops and totally different soil regime.
And then at Lubbock we had people working where water stress was greater and more on the physical problems with soils.
And then of course El Paso.
having the real desert-like conditions.
So as a young scientist, that was really an asset to me, and I always enjoyed that.
And we always got together a couple of times a year, one here in College Station and one at one of those remote units, and talked about our research and teaching and so on.
And that made our professions very lively and stimulating.
Compared to what you had known at Kentucky and Auburn, were these arrangements and opportunities similar?
Did they have research opportunities all across their states through their experiment station and extension services?
They did to some degree, but being smaller states, and like Kentucky is at about the same latitude, it doesn't vary a whole lot.
in north-south direction, there wasn't as much diversity.
And I guess being somewhat prone toward geographic movement, I just liked the potential of a large land area.
And we had people coming in
Morris Bloodworth worked down in the Rio Grande Valley during some of his early career.
And he worked for World Bank a bit.
And so we had people coming in occasionally from other countries like Saudi Arabia and from Great Britain connected with the World Bank.
I remember John Coulter coming in and Mansour Aba Hussein came from Saudi Arabia and did a
a post-doctoral here, a sabbatical here.
And so eventually I had research contracts with the Saudis and went over there myself.
So the idea that the executive part of the university was promoting that was a sort of a global village
and that we should interact widely, fit it in beautifully with my plans as a soil scientist because I could learn a lot when I went to give a workshop in Saudi Arabia and
And when I had people in from Bali, Indonesia, to talk about soils from volcanic materials and things like that.
And those experiences made teaching much more exciting for both for me and for the students.
Was your appointment a joint appointment with the experiment station and the university?
Yes, it was.

and that of course is true of most all the members of my department and Murray Milford I think was the only one in the department for many years that had an all teaching appointment and he had some administrative responsibilities.
The opportunities
that this joint appointment, I had a third teaching and I had two thirds research.
I think one of the greatest things about my career at Texas A&M from a personal point of view is that I had I could teach soil mineralogy, which was my specialty, my research area.
every year.
I suspect that it's the only institution that has taught soil mineralogy, if not consistently, almost every year.
During my 32 or 33 years of tenure here and Kunze's tenure before, it was taught often.
I don't know exactly the frequency.
And that, I like that.
After having to skip around from
Of course, semester to semester at Auburn, which I found very difficult to do adequately, I liked the continuity.

And I brought so many things into my teaching from the research and made my, you know, talking about something one reads is usually pretty stale compared to talking about something one has observed and written up as research.
And at least it made my work more pleasant.
That evolved into several things.
Just a second.
What did you bring with you in terms of equipment and or note?
What stuff did you bring to put in your office and in your lab?
Well, when I left Wisconsin, M.L.
Jackson had some old atomic models.
And I think I had a few of those that kind of got me started.
Kunze left me some here.
And so I had built up some atomic models, which I used in introducing crystal structures of these various minerals that occur in soils.
And I worked on x-ray equipment at Auburn, and I had the same kind of x-ray equipment here, so that made the transfer of skill and familiarity easy.
And I had built thermal analysis equipment in my master's degree at Kentucky.
I actually inherited thermal analysis equipment here, so there was quite a bit of transfer of familiarity of equipment.
I think the thing that had a synergistic effect, because I taught often, I was under more persuasive power just within my own career to get some text material out.
I was teaching with a book written by a geologist that was intended for researchers and consultants.
at the University of Illinois, and that was very inadequate as a text, so I really was having to develop my own text material.
And so I started about 1974 developing a book to teach with, and we finished it and published it in 1977.
And that book was 900 pages, published through the Division Nine, the Soil and Mineralogy Division of the Soil Science Society of America.
And I was the lead editor on that book.
Dixon and Weed were the names on the book.
And then we published that book totally revised in 1989, and it was 1,200 pages.
So we had lots of material.
The students complained a bit about it.
So we designed another book, and it'll be published in February 2002.
And it'll be a smaller book.
It'll only be 750 pages.
And that gave people in a wide geographic area some visibility of the program at Texas A&M.
And as a consequence of that...
